output.conclusion: By the end of this course, you will have a solid understanding of satellite imagery analysis techniques and their applications, enabling you to contribute effectively to projects involving remote sensing data.
output.introduction: This course provides an intermediate-level exploration of satellite imagery analysis, covering essential concepts, techniques, and applications. It is designed for individuals with some prior experience in remote sensing or image processing.

chapters.description: Overview of satellite imagery, types of sensors (optical, radar), spectral bands, and spatial resolution. Discuss the electromagnetic spectrum and its relevance to remote sensing.
Explore different satellite platforms (Landsat, Sentinel, MODIS) and their characteristics. Understand data acquisition processes, orbit types, and revisit times.
Learn about geometric and atmospheric corrections. Understand the importance of image calibration and rectification for accurate analysis.
Explore contrast stretching, histogram equalization, and spatial filtering techniques to improve image interpretability.

Introduction to supervised and unsupervised classification methods. Discuss training data selection, feature extraction, and classification algorithms (e.g., maximum likelihood, support vector machines).
Learn about different change detection techniques (image differencing, ratioing, post-classification comparison) and their applications in monitoring land cover changes.
Apply satellite imagery analysis for land cover mapping and classification. Discuss accuracy assessment and validation techniques.
Explore the use of satellite imagery in monitoring deforestation, urban sprawl, water quality, and other environmental parameters.
Learn about the use of satellite imagery in precision agriculture, crop monitoring, yield estimation, and irrigation management.
